verse.arabic_text: لَن تَنَالُوا الْبِرَّ حَتَّىٰ تُنفِقُوا مِمَّا تُحِبُّونَ ۚ وَمَا تُنفِقُوا مِن شَيْءٍ فَإِنَّ اللَّهَ بِهِ عَلِيمٌ
verse.translation: You will never achieve righteousness until you spend from that which you love. And whatever you spend of good, Allah is certainly aware of it.

theme_question.correct: The path to true righteousness involves sacrificing what is beloved for Allah's sake.
options: Righteousness is achieved primarily through ritual prayers and fasting.
The path to true righteousness involves sacrificing what is beloved for Allah's sake.
Spending from your wealth is only necessary for the poor.
Allah only accepts charity given from surplus wealth.

educational_notes.verse_context: This verse (3:92) concludes a section in Surah Al Imran that addresses the People of the Book, particularly the Jews and Christians, and their claims regarding faith and practice. It follows discussions about the true religion being Islam, the importance of following Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), and the rejection of false innovations. The verse serves as a universal principle for all believers, emphasizing a core aspect of piety that transcends mere ritual.
educational_notes.theme_explanation: The verse highlights a profound principle of attaining 'Al-Birr' (righteousness, piety, goodness, virtue). It teaches that true righteousness is not merely intellectual assent or outward observance, but requires a deeper level of sacrifice: giving from what one loves most. This act demonstrates sincerity, detachment from worldly possessions, and a strong desire to please Allah. The verse implies that the value of charity is not just in the amount given, but in the quality of what is given and the love one has for it, as Allah is fully aware of all intentions and deeds.
educational_notes.surah_overview: Surah Al Imran is a Medinan surah, named after the family of Imran, which includes Maryam (Mary) and her son Isa (Jesus). It is the third surah of the Quran and continues many themes from Surah Al-Baqarah, particularly concerning the People of the Book. Key themes include: the unity of God (Tawhid) and the refutation of polytheistic and Christian doctrines regarding Jesus; the importance of steadfastness in faith, especially after the Battle of Uhud (which is discussed in detail); the call to Muslims to unite and adhere to the straight path; and lessons on patience, perseverance, and reliance on Allah. The surah emphasizes the concept of Islam as the universal religion of all prophets and calls for deep reflection on Allah's signs.
